intro: Acaena trifida var. pycnacantha, commonly known as the dense-fruited acaena, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its spiny stems and clustered, yellowish flowers. The plant produces small, round, edible berries that are often used by native birds. Its leaves are typically alternate and have a rough, hairy texture. It thrives in a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained conditions and full sun.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena trifida var. pycnacantha is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the northern and central regions of the country. This variant is commonly associated with coastal and lowland areas. It grows in a variety of habitats including forests, shrublands, and rocky soils. The plant is well adapted to the temperate climate of New Zealand.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena trifida var. pycnacantha was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and flowers. However, it has since become invasive, spreading rapidly in native ecosystems. The plant thrives in a variety of habitats, including grasslands and disturbed areas. Its introduction has led to concerns about its impact on local biodiversity and ecological balance.
